name: Anonymous
com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

com:
Multipurpose Tool Edition

Feel free to post tobaccos (no weed allowed), pipes, collections, pics of favorite combos for going /out/, pics of what you're doing with your pipe and any questions you might have.

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?
Get a corncob pipe and a pouch of either Captain Black or Half and Half tobacco, available at most drugstores.
What you'll need: pipe, tobacco, lighter or matches, pipe cleaners, and either a regular old nail or a pipe tool (combination tamper, scoop, and small pick).
All of these together should run you less than $25, still. God help you.

Having trouble keeping your pipe lit? Fill it with less tobacco and smoke it slower than you think you need to, lightly tamping as needed when the smoke starts thinning out.
If you're still having trouble, try filling your pipe this way:

sub: Legitimately dangerous east coast woods general.
com:
So a lot of people remember the storm on May24th weekend of this year that created some of the most historic timber damage dating back past the infamous "ice storm" of the 90s.

I've been working in residential and commercial tree removal and got to see first hand that amount of straight up damage to property from fallen trees, broken tops of Sw, Maple losing large limbs, length wise cracks on co-dominant trees straight onto the house roof, etc.

That being said, the thing that has struck me has been on crown land or in woodlots looking into the treeline now that all the leaves have fallen and seeing the the ridiculous number of danger trees. The other day we were on wooded private property removing some large but otherwise healthy poplar. The primary site hazard is dangerous trees x100. Multiple snags 45 degree angle or greater, a lot of the dead ash trees have now toppled onto healthy or unhealthy trees. Certainly want to be careful winter camping when setting up in the dark, a nice clearing might be underneath a few snags all leaning on each other.

it's about building codes/minimum standards for dwellings more than anything.

i'm guessing mostly it's the fact that jurisdictions haven't really caught up to living offgrid. there really should be a variance for these types of dwellings. if someone wants to buy some land and build their house, install septic, etc etc on their timeline, that should be their right. no one is going to buy a fucking house on a plot of land and then realize "oh shit, it's not on the grid, fuck me, i didn't bother to see if there was electricity!"

like my county (lane, OR) has minimum dwelling sizes, septic/mains/well requirements, etc etc; which make it either outright impossible to buy land, and build a homestead from scratch, or make the permitting/siting process take so long that construction loans aren't feasible. For example: getting a conditional use permit for a dwelling on F2 land requires at least 18 months of paperwork and waiting around while some 25 y/o nitwit planner looks for reasons to deny your build, meanwhile construction loans typically have a 1 year conversion timeline. wife and i lucked out and found a property that already had the CUP on it, otherwise there was no way we could have swung the land purchase and rolled it into our construction loan.

it's such a fucky situation, one that a lot of the naive 20 somethings here completely fail to understand. then again if it were as simple as rolling an RV onto a plot of land and going for it, there wouldn't be any countryside left. Some states are probably more amenable to this kind of thing, but the overall trend seems to be to make moving out into rural areas more and more difficult -- environmentalism gone wild coupled with a subtle/backhanded mommy government hatred of proles and independence.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505971
It applies at any temperature and level of activity. In theory, you could always wear the perfect amount of clothes to not sweat and be fine with nonbreathable gear. In practice, you'll not manage that. Your level of exertion and the temperatures will fluctuate, you will sweat when you're hot, and unless you are literally naked (or change your clothes after sweating) that sweat will stay within your clothing afterwards when you're cold.
>if it’s warm enough to rain
That may be as low as slightly above freezing. You need to exert yourself quite a bit to not need *any* insulative clothing at that temperature.

com:
Good week for mushrooms ahead edition

>Community-based tools for IDing and Cataloguing
Mushroomobserver.org
The Bolete Filter: https://boletes.wpamushroomclub.org/
Inaturalist app (directly draws data from mushroomobserver but is itself a more generalized platform)
Google Scholar: Massive resource for papers and studies regarding current clinical and indigenous uses of medicinal fungi.

If you expect to get a remotely meaningful ID here, you need to be taking photos of the mushroom as you found it, on it's substrate, a clear shot of the top and side view of it, and a clear shot of the gills/pores/stipe/stem or otherwise the entire undercarriage of the mushroom. every detail of the encounter helps, where, when, what was the weather, etc.
If you want people who do this for a living to give their guess on ID's, take all of the above and make quality observations on Mushroomobserver.

This science needs as much redundant ID and loacation data as possible, any observation has value and is a meaningful contribution that takes a few more seconds than just taking a picture of the pretty thing you saw in the woods.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2506039
>How can I make mushrooms to proliferate in an area so the following year has a larger amount of them?

The fruiting body you see on the surface is just one small part of the fungi. Beneath the surface is a mycelium system that spawns the fruiting bodies in an area that consistently produces mushrooms. I assume the best way to proliferate a desired fruiting body is to first proliferate mycelium growth (maybe by spreading nutrient substrate around the area), or to spread spores over the desired area during ideal weather conditions and over an ideal substrate in ideal locations to promote growth (ie under a damp log or on moist sheltered leaf litter during a cool rainy season, dependent on species). Both methods are dependent on local weather and light conditions, because they are done outside of a controlled environment. Large colonies also take a long time to grow and cover a large area, there are many examples in both the eastern and western US of colonies that are hundreds to thousands of acres in size and they are estimated to have taken hundreds to thousands of years to attain that much area. Might be worth a try, I'm not an expert.

last_replies.com:
>Grain side:
Looks more traditional
A good full grain leather lasts longer (lots of low quality 'full' grains that are actually top grain or less
Easier to water proof
>Flesh (suede side):
Runs a few degrees cooler
Takes scrapes easier without showing (especially compared to anything but good full grain leather)
Absorbs water easier
>wildland fire
still uses flesh side cuts for scrapes. most I talk to know that their feet will get wet eventually so if a choice is present, go with flesh.
>suede
is a slice inside the leather so the grain isn't present at all. Usually the weakest cut since less fibers interlink the closer to the flesh you go. This is like minnetonka moccasins leather because you can see the suede appearance on one side rather than flesh on one side and grain on the other.
Also note, a lot of polyurethane (plastic) coated leathers out there today to increase water resistance.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2496881
>mostly desert
There are more than 4,000 species of plants in the Sonoran desert and transition zone of Arizona alone that are known as of the time of this post (this number is for example, over 500 species higher than the known cataloged vascular plant species of NY state). This is not counting fungi or lichen species. It ranks 3rd in the entire US in this metric at the time of this post. More are discovered every year. AZGFD manages over 800 native non-insect animal species. Over 1/4th of AZ is temperate forest, only 2/5ths is true arid.

The largest known fungal colony specimen in the world (also possibly the largest living "animal" in the world) was discovered in OR (Armillaria ostoyae), the largest and possibly oldest clonal tree specimen in the world was found in south-central UT (Pando). The largest and highest scoring trophy Rocky Mountain Elk to date have been consistently taken from AZ (1st in total specimens and highest scores) and UT (2nd, but first if measuring number of trophy Elk per sq mi area).

The climate of every western state is more varied in every measurement than any individual eastern US state. The topography of every wester state is more varied than any eastern US state. The amount of public and ironically even private land in every western state is higher than the amount of public and private lands in every eastern US state (east of the Mississippi), due to the size disparity of eastern and western states.

Budget for a ski season:
Boots: = $500/5 seasons = $100
Skis is same (buy used), so another $100
Poles = $50/5 = $10
Jacket, $200/5 = $40
Pants, $200/5 = $40
socks, helmet, other personal items: $300/5 = $60
Season pass: $800 (your mileage may vary)

Total: $1570/season. Sorry you're poor anon, but frankly if you can't come up with $1570 dollars for a ski season then that's your problem.

Historically, they used to burn much more often and even more severely naturally. It's astonishing how much folks forget things from even just a century ago and even more so how easily data and media can be manipulated to fit it to a desired paradigm. The takeaway is that wildfires were, have been, and always will be a natural feature of the western US and that folks needed to plan and prepare for them rather than try to eliminate them. Part of their natural function or result was to recycle, replenish and renew forest nutrients often allowing them to regrow with even greater biodiversity at their climax until the next cycle hit. Anyone living in a naturally fire prone forest should be aware of this.

name: Anonymous
sub: Beginner Gear General - Poor Fag Edition
com:
I wanted to make a thread for General new gear and where to get it. Also for Larpers and Woodsman alike to avoid the pit falls I fell into when choosing gear for the first time over 2 years ago. i'll try to aim for a good gear loadout under 200$. Also any criticisms or better options should be talked about here.

Ill first go by stating the things no anon should ever cheap out on.
>boots
you should aim for boots over 200$ price range eventually, but if you are just getting started buy military surplus boots. But If you can avoid do not buy the recent desert tan army boots that run 20$. They have very thick soles and no ankle support , its a good way to give yourself a sprang ankle, they are also not very breathable or water proof. But I used them for a year so they are workable but do have a week or 2 brake in period.

Next is backpacks I see many on here choose a military surplus backpack, My experience with a US military molle 2 rucksack is that its usable at best but too heavy. Military sacrifices price and quality material for an indestructible pack that an idiot can't destroy. You are better off with a used frame backpack or internal backpack.

I have found that most milltary backpacks are around 65-120$ a used backpacking bag is around 20$ on shopgoodwill.com. I hear you say that you don't want to stand out in the woods , I would say their are plenty of waterproof rain flys for your bag that come in non-IRreflective camo for 45$ or a Chinese rain fly for 10$ on amazon, which are better than what ever camo you were thinking about buying any how. A good capacity is 65 liters, this is considered 3 day bag but if your smart you can fit rations for a full week in it. 55 liters is fine but the limit for fitting a sleeping bag and not limiting the gear you might want to take. Finally you need to have a waist support for your backpack as well as a frame , this should go without saying a duffel bag is a pain to hull around 5 miles.

last_replies.com:
>>2503889
There are many different accessories that can be helpful when fishing from a kayak, depending on your specific needs and preferences. Some common accessories that many kayak fishermen like to have include:

A fishing rod holder to keep your rod secure while you paddle or fish.

A fish finder to help you locate fish and other underwater structures.

A bait bucket or cooler to keep your bait fresh and store your catch.

A paddle leash to prevent your paddle from floating away if you drop it.

A dry bag to protect your belongings from water and keep them dry.

A waterproof map case to keep your maps and other important documents safe from water.

A kayak anchor to help you stay in one spot while fishing.

A waterproof flashlight or headlamp for fishing at night or in low-light conditions.

A landing net to help you safely bring your catch aboard your kayak.

A kayak cart to make it easier to transport your kayak to and from the water.

It is also important to have all necessary safety gear, such as a personal flotation device (PFD) and a whistle or other signaling device. Make sure to check local regulations for any other required gear or permits.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2496241
"Van Life" is best enjoyed if you have some reason to travel in order to make that way of living worthwhile. The convenience of living rent/motel free means that a 3 month trip becomes a lot more achievable to those with only a couple grand savings.

Driving a van is a bit of a PITA and you will want to do short hops from town to town and do a bit of exploring, then rest up overnight and go another 30mins/hour down the road and explore that place, or do whatever.
Great if you're travelling to rock climb every major spot in the country, or surf every good beach, go to every national park or go to every Six Flags ect. You kind of need a directive to make the most of it.

As a permanent way of living it is one step departed from living in a motel or a tent.
If you are intending on doing it for a cheap existence and not a holiday then go find a homeless community like Slab City and live there in your van because that's the true permanent living solution. You won't run into any issues with squatting there.

If you have a job, rent a place because the benefits far outweigh the money you save living inside a 3x2meter box.

sub: Why do people like kukris so much?
com: I bought myself a kukri a year or so ago, used it extensively as a camp duty tool. It really seems like a neat idea in theory but in practice it just doesn't work for me no matter how hard I try. It's too cumbersome to be a good replacement for a knife, it's too light to be a good replacement for a hatchet. It's also a pain in the ass to take care of due to the fact that it has a recurve shape. The only scenario where it's actually reasonable to use it is clearing slightly thick branches or really thick weeds where a regular machete doesn't have enough weight to cut through. I can't count how many times I found myself wishing I packed proper tools instead. Why are people so obsessed about these things? Have I fallen for a meme?

last_replies.com:
West Coast Trail on Vancouver Island is a good 5-6 day haul, unfettered beaches, old shipwreck rubbish, crashing waves with nothing but ocean between you and Japan, waterfalls and ladders, self-propelled cable gondolas over clear rivers, humpback whales and bald eagles, lush PNW forests...a little tent restaurant in the middle of the trail with $25 burgers, Washington State visible across the Juan de Fuca Strait going south..but as usual on the Island, there can be relentless rain and ankle-deep mud, with a full pack you may only clear 10 kilometers on an inclement day.

Definitely something to consider.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Hell yeah. One of the most fun part of motorcycling is the ease of camping. This is me after firing the bike into a park that was closed for the season via the pedestrian footpath, and I decided to bring luxury as I was staying for 3 days and brought a tent. Normally, I sleep under my cover - I bought a dark green ATV cover for the cruiser, as it has enough space underneath it to cover the bike fully while also allowing me to ground sleep underneath it. This time, I wanted some comforts, and turns out a 6 man tent will fit a decent wheelbase machine nicely. Did a few wrapped in a greatcoat under that cover while the night temperature hut freezing, which was amusing waking up with frost on the cover to then go riding down the same roads. I always have that green cover and a flat-packable woodstove in my saddlebag, just in case I feel like getting silly. Dirtbag camping is a riot!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Typically if I'm camping it's because there's a trail or climb that's too long to do in one day or there's multiple trails I want to do that start at the same trailhead but break off somewhere later and I don't want to do those initial miles more than once. So if I'm camping it's two to five nights at the same spot some miles, but not too many, from a trailhead.
Loathe the type of backpacking where you pack up and carry your shit every day. And if I'm anywhere near my car I usually just sleep in it rather than setting up the tent.

Only multitool I need. Leatherman wave.
Got it as a gift ages ago and really love it as a good alrounder. You have quick access to the cutting tools and it has stuff you can at least get some use out of, rather than 50 features I do neither want nor need. It's built like a tank and has withstood some insane abuse by me, including leaving it outside for over a year in a bowl that collected rain and snow. All I got was this matte patina, it still works perfectly.
It's very expensive, but you notice the quality your money gets you at least and for me due to the memories I made with it and it being a gift by my parents I have become emotionally attached to it at this point.
>tell me why you think it's the perfect one for you
Has all the features I regularly use, but not many more. Sturdy, doesn't get damaged easily, good form factor, gets the job done for basically any task, be it cutting wire, holding things, pulling thorns out of my skin, cracking nuts, cutting things, or anything related. Pair it with a extra knife for fishing that is easy to clean and you got 80% of usecases covered and can probably improvise something with it for the other 20%.
